comments:
When devloping SWT using a JRE that doesn't support AWT, the AWTStarter is
putting errors into the .log file.  It'd be nice to catch the AWTError that's
thrown if the AWT toolkit is not found or can't be initialized (see the
getDefaultToolkit()'s javadoc).  Or even better would be to avoid calling the
AWTStarter when not launching a JFC remote vm.

!ENTRY org.eclipse.jem.proxy 2 0 2005-05-21 12:40:31.938
!MESSAGE 
+++ Warning +++: Sat May 21 12:40:31 EDT 2005    Project (KaffeTest)-VM for
KaffeTest:err>
    Exception in thread "Thread-2" java.awt.AWTError: Cannot load AWT toolkit: 
       at java.awt.Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit() (/usr/local/lib/libgcj.so.6.0.0)
       at org.eclipse.jem.internal.proxy.vm.remote.AWTStarter$1.run() (Unknown
Source)
       at .GC_start_routine (/usr/local/lib/libgcj.so.6.0.0)
       at .__clone (/lib/libc-2.3.4.so)
    Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: 
       at java.lang.Class.forName(java.lang.String, boolean,
java.lang.ClassLoader) (/usr/local/lib/libgcj.so.6.0.0)
       at java.lang.Class.forName(java.lang.String) (/usr/local/lib/libgcj.so.6.0.0)
       at java.awt.Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit() (/usr/local/lib/libgcj.so.6.0.0)
       ...3 more

Could you please append the complete stack trace? I don't know where we are
calling the getToolkit so I can't narrow down why. Thanks.

That's the full stack trace I'm getting.  I found the getDefaultToolkit() call
in question in AWTStarter - line 30.

It looks like this may be preventing the beaninfo cache from being generated. 
The VE comes up fine if you have the beaninfo cache left over from the Sun VM...
but if you do a clean, the cache does not get regenerated, but no other errors
are logged.  The editor comes up without any settings made to the UI and the
property sheet blank.

Hmmm... disregard that last comment. There was a delay before the cache was
flushed and showed up on the disk.  But it's still a puzzle as to why it comes
up properly with the Sun beaninfo, but is broken with the GCJ beaninfo.  I'll do
a diff of their respective caches to look for clues.

I don't think the call to AWTStarter is the problem. We could squash the trace.
It would be nice if we knew there was no AWT but I don't know how to do that
quickly. If we knew in some easy way we could also not show the awt/swing
palette too.

But it can't be the AWTStarter that is causing the problem. As you stated, it
must be something else. Beside this trace what are the symptoms of the problem
other than the call to AWTStarter.

By the way, the cache is delayed five minutes before being written or written at
shutdown or project close.
No new info, so closing for now.
